image.altText: Harry Badcock and Charlotte Grey stand with their young son near a food van at a festival

props.synopsis: Harry and Charlotte celebrated their first wedding anniversary with a music festival for friends and family. Now, they are the organisers of a boutique festival in Tasmania's north-west.

title.children: Fans are 'hungry' for music, and this Tasmanian couple may have the answer to keeping festivals alive

image.altText: Saline 1

props.synopsis: One senior clinician at a major Sydney hospital has described the ongoing situation as "a complete sh**show".

title.children: 'You're being asked to act as a gatekeeper': Doctors say they are still being forced to conserve IV fluids

image.altText: A woman with a neutral expression looks at the camera. In the background, medical equipment is visible.

props.synopsis: Sholbaana Kuular and her family have firsthand experience with regard to how racist Russian society can be, but a proposed new law that would limit the number of migrant children in classrooms has outlined how discrimination often starts at state level.

title.children: Inside the 'horrible machine' of Russian racism, where bullying starts at state level

image.altText: A hand holding a phone displaying a map

props.synopsis: Since the start of the Gaza war, Israel has been deploying a tactic known as GPS "spoofing", which is designed to fool enemy missiles but has also had detrimental impacts on civilian life.

title.children: In the Middle East, dating apps, food delivery and map navigation are leading everyone to Beirut Airport

image.altText: A woman with brown curly hair stands on a ladder to get a view of the level of a water tank.

props.synopsis: As summer approaches, volunteer fire fighter Suzie Gifford shares her bushfire plan, how she prepares her home against an ember attack, and what's in her emergency kit.

title.children: This bushfire season should you stay or go? This firefighter has some advice for that

image.altText: A drone shot of a 3D printed neighbourhood in Texas

props.synopsis: Texas just opened its biggest 3D-printed neighbourhood as a solution to its acute housing problem. Could it be the solution the Australian construction has been waiting for?

title.children: A four-tonne machine just printed a house in the US. What can Australia learn?

image.altText: a group of men look at a BYD car in front of a BYD logo

props.synopsis: Despite tariffs and a slowing global demand for electric vehicles in recent months, China is steaming ahead with its transition to EVs.

title.children: 'The Chinese offensive is visible everywhere': The changing face of the auto industry

image.altText: A newspaper lies open with a story on one side headlined "Baby alone in murder house" and a picture of a boy.

props.synopsis: The case is said to have struck at the heart of Melbourne and 47 years later, it's yet to reach a conclusion.Â

title.children: The Easey Street killings became Victoria's most serious and longest running cold case, and it's not over yet

image.altText: The Premier, Health Minister, and candidate and a youth worker stand in a line and smile outside a hospital.

props.synopsis: The Liberals promised $120 million over five years for a new cardiac centre for the state's north at the Launceston General Hospital, but the state budget revealed no funding allocation for the project.

title.children: Did you miss? ðŸ“£ Tasmanian Liberals blasted after 'priority' Northern Heart Centre election promise not funded in state budget

image.altText: Alison Donnan holds up a bit of Tupperware.

props.synopsis: Tupperware's plastic may be famously indestructible, but the US-based company filed for bankruptcy this week. It's cause for reflection from the Australians who sold the containers to party-goers across decades.

title.children: As Tupperware files for bankruptcy, the memories live on for the Australians who sold the famous plastic

image.altText: A vintage-style illustration of two boxers fighting in a ring, surrounded by a crowd

props.synopsis: The past 12 years have delivered a spectacular meteor shower of defamation cases brought by celebrities, politicians and businessfolk, and fought out on the national stage of the Federal Court. ABC Long Reads has the story of how it all began.Â

title.children: The multi-million-dollar celebrity court cases that sometimes have a nasty habit of backfiring

image.altText: Phillip Mehrtens sitting in a chair after being freed. He has long hair and a beard.

props.synopsis: Armed pro-independence rebels in Indonesia's Papua region have released New Zealand man Philip Mehrtens after holding him hostage for more than 19 months.

title.children: NZ pilot freed after being held hostage by armed rebels in Indonesia's Papua region for 19 months

image.altText: Bush at the proposed site of a hydrogen plant.

props.synopsis: It's the game-changing policy Labor didn't hold back on selling ahead of the 2022 SA election. But making a promise in opposition is one thing and actually delivering it in government is another, and the next three months loom as crucial for the hydrogen project's future.

title.children: Is a green hydrogen power play at risk of becoming a mirage in the scrub?

image.altText: A woman crouching down with an animal in a pouch, in the desert at dawn.

props.synopsis: A number of native animals, extinct in New South Wales for more than 100 years, are reclaiming the desert in Sturt National Park and scientists are trying to teach them how to survive predators like feral cats.Â

title.children: These native species were locally extinct but are now reclaiming their desert homeland

image.altText: MrBeast

props.synopsis: A class action lawsuit filed against MrBeast, Amazon and others alleges mistreatment behind the scenes of the Beast Games TV show.

title.children: MrBeast offered them a chance at $5 million. Now Beast Games contestants allege 'sexual harassment' and 'dangerous' conditions

image.altText: Two men wearing suits. One is smiling and looking at the camera, the other has a hand to his chest

props.synopsis: Prime Minister Michel Barnier's government has a distinctly more conservative tilt than that of his predecessor Gabriel Attal.

title.children: France appoints new government in shift to right

image.altText: Lions players leap into a big group hug in celebration

props.synopsis: Brisbane will face Sydney in the 2024 AFL grand final after the Lions stood up in the final moments to win a classic preliminary final against Geelong.

title.children: Lions never stop believing to edge Cats in preliminary final for the ages

image.altText: James Tedesco of the Roosters celebrates after scoring a try

props.synopsis: Sydney Roosters captain James Tedesco has scored twice in his 250th NRL match, guiding the Tricolours to a semifinal win over Manly.

title.children: Captain Teddy leads Roosters to semifinal win over Sea Eagles

image.altText: A person looks inside a building with rubble strewn throughout it

props.synopsis: It comes as the Lebanese health ministry raises the death toll from an Israeli strike on Beirut's suburbs to at least 37, including three children and seven women.

title.children: Gaza officials say at least 22 people killed in Israeli strike on school

image.altText: A close up of the preserved tree stump, just after it was unearthed from the sand, white beach and blue sky in background.

props.synopsis: Researchers and local Indigenous people say a beautifully preserved metre-wide and 40-centimetres-high tree stump may be a thousand-year-old messenger with a story to share about climate change.

title.children: Why this ancient stump could unlock secrets about climate change

image.altText: a portrait of a man sitting at an outdoor table in his backyard

props.synopsis: Youth crime could decide next month's Queensland election. Thousands of victims are heading to the polls demanding change, but will locking kids up solve the problem in the long run?

title.children: A teenage home invader murdered Lee's wife. He hopes the Queensland election will help spark change

image.altText: Scott Barrett holds up the Bledisloe Cup.

props.synopsis: The Wallabies launch a late comeback but it is to no avail, as the All Blacks triumph 31-28 following a pulsating climax to the opening Bledisloe Cup Test in Sydney.

title.children: All Blacks retain Bledisloe Cup after holding off fast-finishing Wallabies

image.altText: GettyImages-2173520374

props.synopsis: Alex Carey extends Australia's ODI winning streak, as England's batters fall short at Headingley.Â

title.children: Carey leads Australia to victory with solid knock amid a racket of Headingley booing

image.altText: Max Verstappen, Lando Norris and Lewis Hamilton, posing for a photo, arm in arm

props.synopsis: Lando Norris has qualified on pole for Sunday's Formula 1 Singapore Grand Prix, while world championship leader Max Verstappen will start alongside his British challenger.

title.children: Title rivals qualify first and second for Singapore Grand Prix

image.altText: A video still of Tom Gleeson with his mouth and eyes open as he says 'HARD' on the set of Hard Quiz.

props.synopsis: You might not be on my show but that doesn't mean I'm going to make it easier for you.

title.children: Buckle up, it's time to test your trivia know-how, HARD!

image.altText: The Menendez family and their grisly story gets the Ryan Murphy treatment

props.synopsis: American Horror Story creator Ryan Murphy is once again picking from the horrific crimes of the recent past to create his newest mini-series Monsters: The Lyle and Erik Menendez Story.Â Â

title.children: Lyle and Erik Menendez murdered their parents in the 1990s. Now Netflix is telling their story

image.altText: Donny stares into the camera as he sits at the back of a bus wearing a yellow jacket, with antlers photoshopped behind him.

props.synopsis: The Emmy Award-winning show Baby Reindeer has brought stalking back into the zeitgeist. But what drives people to stalk others and how should their victims respond?

title.children: 'Any attention is fuel': The five types of stalker and how to stop them

image.altText: Close-up of a hand pulling a bottle of milk from the shelf in a supermarket.

props.synopsis: Food Standards Australia New Zealand research shows 22 per cent of us misunderstand best-before dates, and 33 per cent misunderstand use-by dates.

title.children: How long can you eat something past its 'best-before' date?

image.altText: Cars can be seen submerged in water in flooding in Wajima

props.synopsis: Flooding in central Japan's Noto region kills at least one person, prompting evacuation orders for tens of thousands and causing blackouts for more than 6,000 households.

title.children: Thousands evacuated, one killed after record rains douse central Japan

image.altText: Three people in military gear and three people in police uniform are seen from behind.

props.synopsis: At least 53 people have died in Mexico's Sinaloa state as factions of its powerful cartel clash over the arrest of leader Ismael "El Mayo" Zambada in the United States.

title.children: Ambassador denies US responsibility for Sinaloa violence as death toll rises over 50

image.altText: Ali Brigginshaw of the Broncos passing to her left in an NRLW match

props.synopsis: Brisbane has one hand on a record fifth NRLW minor premiership after coming from behind to thump St George Illawarra 44-14 in Townsville.

title.children: Broncos close in on minor premiership as Knights ensure another finals berth

image.altText: Amanda Stoker looks to her side while attending a parliamentary committee

props.synopsis: An LNP candidate has withdrawn her support for a rabbi who repeatedly compared homosexuality to paedophilia, bestiality, and incest.

title.children: LNP candidate pleads ignorance after pulling support for rabbi with 'extreme' anti-homosexual views

image.altText: Jenny Adams, in black shirt with brown hair, smiles widely next to man in white shirt, whose hand she holds. He also smiles.

props.synopsis: Ever wanted to try sleeping apart from your partner but feared the judgement of others or perhaps your partner's reaction? These people have not only tried it but love it. Here's how they make it work.

title.children: Sleeping apart made these couples happier and their relationships better. Could it work for you?
